div.head: Introduction
div.p: This is the codebook for a pilot project researching the possibility of using a distant reading system for reading Dutch online book reviews. The question that I am interested in is what issues are discussed in the reviews and determine people's appreciation of the books that they discuss. The research is undertaken in the context of the database of Online Dutch Book Response (ODBR) discussed in Boot (2017).

The coding system is based on the system devised by Yvette Linders and described in her thesis Met waardering gelezen (2014). I modified and extended the system in several respects. See this powerpoint (in Dutch) for an idea of what I'm trying to achieve. Mail me for more information.

item.label: A
item.gloss: Discussion of tone and language use in the work, w.r.t. word choice, syntax and its connotations.
item.note: stijl, taal, toon, ondertoon, penvoering, zinnetjes, zinnen, toonzetting, woorden, woordspelingen, woordenstroom, formuleringen, taalgebruik, vocabulaire, verteltrant, schrijfwijze, taalbeheersing, woordkeus, schrijven, beschrijven, weergeven, vertellen, benoemen, formuleren, op papier zetten, noteren
vorm, vormvast: assigned by Linders to Structure, here seen as references to style
'Wieringa kan vertellen': J-A 15 (it isn't mentioned what is good about it, so keep it at 15)
'Wieringa kan verhalen vertellen': A-D 15 (applicable are J, A and D, choose A and D)

item.label: B
item.gloss: Discussion of the macrostructure of the text, relations between the chapters or other textual components of the text.
item.note: structuur, orde, ordeloosheid, sprongen in ruimte of tijd, vermenging, fragmentarisch, hoofdstukken, alinea's, lijnen, hoofdlijen, zijlijntjes, vooruitwijzingen, flash-backs, patronen, perspectiefwisselingen, 'rond' verhaal, compositie, vervlechten, in elkaar zetten, componeren, verknopen, onderbreken, verbinden, vermengen
lijnen, hoofdlijen, zijlijntjes: could be seen as Plot?
perspectief(wisselingen): is perspective part of Structure? It is often mentioned
verhaalmotief moved from G to here as it does not necessarily about topic

item.label: C
item.gloss: Discussion of setting background of the story, in time, space, social background.
item.note: ruimte, tijd, decor, milieu-tekening, schets van milieu, sfeer
Can also be indicated by names of specific settings: Amsterdam, the Sixties, high society, political circles

item.label: D
item.gloss: Discussion of events and ending of the story
item.note: plot, verhaal, verhaaldraad, slot, ontknoping, historie, handelingen, episoden, voorvallen
Can also be applied if say a specific episode is recounted
het idee van het boek: probaby usually refers to the plot

item.label: E
item.gloss: Discusses how conversations between characters are represented
item.note: dialoog, gesprek, woordenwisseling, uitspraak, vertellen, spreken

item.label: F
item.gloss: Discussion of characters in the book
item.note: personages, figuur, hoofdpersoon, karakter, mens, tegenspelerhoofdrol, bijrol, persoonlijkheid, sujet, held, type
Can also be used when characters are mentioned by name or profession etc.
Bildungsroman: F-G (theme is people)

item.label: G
item.gloss: Discussion about the topic that are written about.
item.note: thema, idee, probleem, problematiek, gedachte, romanthese, visie, inzicht
Topic can also be mentioned by name rather than by category
Within the present coding systsem there is no way to indicate exactly what topic is being discussed

item.label: H
item.gloss: Discussion of symbolism or metaphors in the work
item.note: symbool, symbolisme, beeldspraak
Specifif symbols can also be mentioned
mooi beeld can refer to symbolism, but more usually is just refers to a beautiful sketch

item.label: I
item.gloss: Discussion of paratextual and non-textual data, such as title, cover, publisher, genre indication, etc
item.note: uitgever, titel, illustratie, afbeelding, foto, flaptekst, papier, verschijnen, presenteren
Genre indication: only code if the genre is thematized: for a thriller, it's pretty tame

item.label: J
item.gloss: Discussion of author of the book and his/her poetics, intentions, person
item.note: auteur, schrijver, schrijfester, intentie bedoeling, willen
Name of specific author is also an indication
Discussion about autobiographical aspects of book: J 8
If a review says that an author can write, that is not necessarily just about style, and therefore: J 15 1 p (rather than J-A)

item.label: K
item.gloss: Discussion of the book as a whole or of parts of the book, where no reference is mode to specific aspects
item.note: boek, werk, roman, verhaal, vertelling, deel, hoofdstuk, slot
verhaal is a difficult case, that will sometimes be just another word for the work as a whole, but in other cases may refer to the plot.

item.label: L
item.gloss: Discussion of other aspects
item.note: Have not yet seen a case where this category was necessary

list.head: Characteristic

item.gloss: Discussion of the efficiency with which the desired effects were obtained.
item.note: efficient, zuinig, ter zake, details, uitvoering, (on)gecontroleerd, onopgesmukt, uitgesponnen, karig, lang, kort, langzaam
Includes negative remarks about volume of book: te dik
traag used negatively (traag verhaal): D 1 -1 n
moet geduld hebben (negative): K 1 -1 n
met gemak geschreven I interpret easy of writing as written efficiently
geconcentreerde stijl: A 1 1 p

item.gloss: Discussion of the extent to which elements form a logical whole
item.note: samenhang(end), combinatie, kloppen met, overeenkomen met
E.g. discussion whether a character and a plot turn are compatible.
geforceerde stijl: I interperet this as a style not fitting the subject or the rest of the writing, i.e. as lack of coherence: A 4 -1 n

item.gloss: Discussion of continuity in a single aspect
item.note: ontwikkeling, verandering, verschuiving, groei, afwisseling
May be applied e.g. (with end of scale -1) for characters that don't show any development.

item.gloss: Discyssion of whether a work is impressive or powerful, whether it contains energy or vitality
item.note: Hevig, gematigd, zacht, vlammend, baldadig, sterk, bravoure, uitbundig, springlevend, speels, vaart, tam, mat verdorring, vitaal, levenloos, landerig, vlot, vlak, leven, flitsend, ongeremd
gekunstelde stijl: A 4 -1 n
vlot geschreven: A 4 1 p
levendig om te lezen, vlot te lezen, however: A 18
bizar is a difficult word. Can be used positively in this category, or negatively in category 8
pakkend: moved from 9 to 4
sensatie (in a negative sense): K 4 1 n (too lively)

item.gloss: Discussion of whether a work is literary, about the depth of a work, about its complexity or layeredness, about intellectualism and about whether it stimulates the intellect
item.note: Literatuur, lectuur, diepgang, boeiend, briljant, intellectueel, geniaal, scherpzinnig, inzicht, zwaarwichtig, onbenullig, interessant, geraffineerd, triviaal
Removed fascinerend as it is certainly not only used for literary or serious work
intrigerend: even though suspense novels can also be called intriguing?
jongensboek as a reproach: K 5 -1 n
ernst was humour, but more suitable here
volwassen: might be used to indicate seriousness, but is also often used when an author of children's books has written a book for adults.
uitgewerkte personages: F 5 (though vividness and credibility might be considered too)
oppervlakkig personage: F 5 -1 n
iets te vertellen hebben: J 5 1 p
Use this characteristic for references to intertextuality

item.gloss: Discussion of humour in the work
item.note: Humor, satire, ironie, kolderiek, spot, spotziek, komisch, joligheid, meligheid, cabaret, vermakelijk, hilarisch, flauw
Linders here also includes what is amusing (vermakelijk or cheerful. I moved these to characteristics amusing (18) and upbeat (16).
irony and geestig are subtle humour: 6-20
glimlach is subtle humour : 6-20

item.gloss: Discussion of whether a work or aspect is clear, easily understandable, including of things that become clear immediately or only later in the work.
item.note: toegankelijk, eenvoudig, makkelijk, moeilijk, helder, duidelijk, onverklaard, onontleed, uitdrukkelijk, nauw-verholen, suggestief, cryptisch, geen hoogte kijgen van, verwarring, schimmig
Linders included spannend, which seems misleading.

item.gloss: Discussion of agreement with reality or credibility
item.note: realistisch, gelijkend, onwezenlijk, geloven, herkennen, (on)herkenbaar, levensecht, overtuigend, ongeloofwaardig, onnatuurlijk, sprookjesachtig.
gekunstelde karakters: F 8 -1 n
filmisch: A 8
Linders includes here fantasie, and that is OK if it is meant to stress lack of realism. But for imagination I created a separate characteristic; it need not conflict with credibility.

item.gloss: Discussion of whether a work or an aspect of the work is emotional, expresses emotions, or evokes emotion
item.note: snijdend, emotie, gevoel, gevoelig, voelen, verdriet, melancholie, ergernis, hartverwarmend, ontroerend, aangrijpend, indringend, aandoenlijk, weemoedig

raak geschreven: A 8-9 (though efficiency, vividness and clarity would also be defensible, or even realism); compare treffend. In raak, I see as the essential element that the reader is surprised or hit by the fittingness of the description, in treffend the element of fittingness is less important.
poëtisch: 5-9 (withouit further indications, probably A 5-9 1 p).
inspirerend: 9-13
An ending that is bevredigend is both emotionally acceptable and credible: D 8-9
sentiment: both emotion and not subtle: I code these separately, as 9 en 20 -1. niet sentimenteel: emotion and subtle, 9-20.

item.gloss: Discussion of whether a work or an aspect of it can teach the reader something, explain things or provide insight
item.note: leren, uitleggen, ogen openen voor, begrijpen, aantonen, laten zien
Moral lessons belong to 13

item.gloss: Discussion of whether a work or aspect of it is religious, has religious meaning, or whether religion plays an important part in it. Other end of scale: atheism.
item.note: stichtelijk, goed-christelijk, names of religions

item.gloss: Discussion whether a work or an aspect of it is socially or politically meaningful. Antonym: apolitical. If the reviewer rejects the political views or objects to political content as such: code as 12 1 n
item.note: maatschappij, samenleving, ideologie, geëngageerd
navelstaarderij: I interpret as a-social interest, 12 -1 n

item.gloss: Discussion of whether the work expresses or discusses ethical norms or prevailing ideas of good and evil. Other end of scale: amoral. Immoral or objections to morality in general: code as 13 1 n
item.note: (on)gevaarlijk, moraliserend, verontrustend, problematiek, probleem

een heroïsch verhaal: F 13 1 p; possibly, if there are overtones of admiration, F 9-13 1 p. held, if used in the general sense, is a moral characteristic F 13. If used in the sense of 'character', just code F (15?)
Also used when the question is raised how morally we would act in the described situation.

item.gloss: Discussion of whether the work or an aspect of it is new or original
item.note: origineel, oorspronkelijk, eigenzinnig, onvervalst, nieuw, bekend, cliché, zoveelste, versleten, creatief, afwijken, overeenkomen, variëren, imitatie, gemeenplaatsen, experimenteel, onnavolgbaar, persoonlijk, verrassend
maf in positive sense is original
Also original: vernieuwend, verfrissend
allebehalve voorspelbaar: shows originality, but may be applied at multiple levels
klassiek verhaal: D 14 -1 p (positively appreciated lack of originality)

item.gloss: General evaluations where non of the other characteristics apply
item.note: goed, slecht, voortreffelijk, knap, uitstekend, mooi, fantastisch
General cannot have a scale associated with it. If end of scale has nevertheless been coded, it will be ignored.
General judgment about book: good book, wonderful book: K 15 p
General judgment about writer, such as a very capable writer: J 15 p

item.gloss: Discusson of whether a work is optimistic, upbeat or pessimistic and gloomy. Not in Linders
item.note: Optimistisch, pessimistisch, zwart, inktzwart, nachtmerrie
Good example: donker boek

item.gloss: Discussion of the extent to which to work or its aspect show imagination. Not in Linders
item.note: (rijke) verbeelding(skracht), fantasie(vol)

item.gloss: Discussion whether the work is a joy to read. Antonym: boring. Not in Linders
item.note: vervelend, saai, leuk, lekker
lekker leesboek, lekker om te lezen, heerlijk om te lezen, levendig om te lezen: K 18
Genoegen, kostelijk: moved from general/other to this category

item.gloss: Discussion of the suspenseful character of the work or an aspect, including the feeling of suspense in the reader. Not in Linders
item.note: spannend, retespannend

I removed suspense from the general category of emotion. There are many works that are nor particularly emotional in any sense except for the feeling of suspense that they evoke in the reader. I seems more usefull to keep this code separate.

item.gloss: Discussion of the subtlety and refinement of the work. Not in Linders
item.note: refined, hoogdravend, bombastisch
sober, ingehouden: moved from Efficient to Subtle
gezwollen, bombast, subtiel, ingetogen: moved from Intensity/vividness to Subtle
traag used positively (traaf en geduldig verteld verhaal): Subtle
moet geduld hebben (positively): K 20 1 p
zuiver: moved from religion to this category
elegant: included in this category

item.gloss: discussion of whether the reader can identify with the book or some aspect of it. Not in Linders
item.note: identificeren, invoelbaar, inleven, zich herkennen in

This was a category that Linders included in the pilot version of her system but removed from the final version. She argues that in the small number of cases where it was used, the phenomenon might as well be coded as credibility or emotion. Because of its importance in reading research I decided to maintain the category.
Category is also used to code pakte me meeslepend, meegevoerd etc. (though pakkend is merely intense)

list.note: pff can mean many different things: sense of relief at end of boring book, heavily impressed by moving story. Will only be coded if meaning is clear.

item.gloss: At mentioned end of scale but overdoing it. Originality e.g. is considered good, but work has too much of it
At mentioned end of scale: on e.g. the 'amusing'-scale, work is amusing, not boring.
Scale is mentioned but it is unclear at what end this work is, or it is somewhere in between.
At other end of scale: on e.g. the 'amusing'-scale, work is boring, not amusing.

item.term: At other end of scale but overdoing it. e.g. too conservative: 14 -1! n

item.label: p
item.gloss: Reveiewer apreciates the mentioned phenomenon
item.note: aardig: usually the positive word in an otherwise negative environment. But interpretation depends on context.

item.label: u
item.gloss: Reviewer expresses no (discernible) opinion about mentioned phenomenon

item.label: n
item.gloss: Reviewer dislikes the mentioned phenomenon

item.label: r
item.term: for a certain group of readers
item.gloss: The opinion given represent how a certain group of readers might evaluate the book
item.note: a story fit for schoolboys, for many people this will be moving
jongensboek, if used as an observation

item.label: w
item.gloss: The opinion given is about another work by the same author

item.label: g
item.gloss: The opinion given is a general opinion, not about this work. Not in Linders
item.note: I dislike symbolism, suspense is what counts

item.label: t
item.gloss: The opinion given is about another author or his/her works
item.note: Weg met de Gipharten (if used in discussion of a book by another author): K 15 -1 n t

item.label: f
item.gloss: The opinion given is that of a teacher, friend, or other reviewer, not the reviewer's own. Not in Linders
item.note: If opinion from other person (f) about other book (w): code as f. Example: De NRC-recensie over dit boek zei dat het qua thematiek tegenover Joe Speedboot staat: G 15 f. Can also be used for unspecified others after all the hype (I had expected more): K 15 p f (p because the opinion of the other persons is positive).

list.item: Especially in longer reviews, all aspects tend to be discussed: plot and characters and style. So the coding might become very similar? But: in one review I might have 5 character aspects (in combination with different characteristics), in another one only one.
Cannot make a distinction between very enthousiastic and moderately positive
Do I need an aspect to take into account obervations, theories, thoughts, general statements included in a story?
